articles.headline: Trump Revives Keystone Pipeline Rejected by Obama
articles.snippet: The new president continued dismantling his predecessor’s policies by clearing the way for a project at the heart of the battle over climate change.
articles.abstract: The new president continued dismantling his predecessor’s policies by clearing the way for a project at the heart of the battle over climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump sharply changed the federal government’s approach to the environment on Tuesday as he cleared the way for two major oil pipelines that had been blocked, and set in motion a plan to curb regulations that slow other building projects.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Coral Davenport

articles.headline: Trump Injects High Risk Into Relations With China
articles.snippet: As he tosses aside decades of American trade policy, President Trump could also go his own way on other issues with China, including Taiwan and the South China Sea.
articles.abstract: As he tosses aside decades of American trade policy, President Trump could also go his own way on other issues with China, including Taiwan and the South China Sea.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For China, President Trump’s scrapping of the American-brokered Pacific trade agreement is a chance to extend Beijing’s economic and political influence. And it is an opportunity to deepen ties with its neighbors in Asia.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: A Supreme Court Pick Is Promised. A Political Brawl Is Certain.
articles.snippet: Three federal appeals court judges appear to be the leading Supreme Court candidates, but Democrats, still stung over the snub of Judge Merrick B. Garland, have vowed to oppose whomever the president picks.
articles.abstract: Three federal appeals court judges appear to be the leading Supreme Court candidates, but Democrats, still stung over the snub of Judge Merrick B. Garland, have vowed to oppose whomever the president picks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Tuesday that he would reach a decision this week on his nominee to fill the nearly yearlong vacancy on the Supreme Court, a choice that will plunge the nation’s capital into what promises to be an all-consuming political fight only weeks into his presidency.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Doubts Arise as Investors Flock to Crowdfunded Start-Ups
articles.snippet: Advocates of a new law that aims to make it easier for businesses to raise capital worry whether investors are getting the information they need.
articles.abstract: Advocates of a new law that aims to make it easier for businesses to raise capital worry whether investors are getting the information they need.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Ryan Feit left behind his lucrative career at a private equity firm to chase the dream of crowdfunding.

articles.headline: Mexico’s Potential Weapons if Trump Declares War on Nafta
articles.snippet: The United States’ southern neighbor must convince President Trump that if he blows up the trade agreement, his country will suffer, too.
articles.abstract: The United States’ southern neighbor must convince President Trump that if he blows up the trade agreement, his country will suffer, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: How could Mexico inflict the most damage on the United States?

articles.headline: Why Women Quit Working: It’s Not for the Reasons Men Do
articles.snippet: Men have been the focus of concern about a stubborn trend of working-age Americans neither working nor looking for jobs. But the trend applies to women, too.
articles.abstract: Men have been the focus of concern about a stubborn trend of working-age Americans neither working nor looking for jobs. But the trend applies to women, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: The go-to explanations for why so many men — even in their prime working years — have dropped out of the labor force do not apply to Krystin Stevenson.

articles.headline: Netflix and CBS Try to Shake Up Reality TV
articles.snippet: With “Hunted” from CBS and “Ultimate Beastmaster” from Netflix, the outlets are trying something new in a sleepy genre.
articles.abstract: With “Hunted” from CBS and “Ultimate Beastmaster” from Netflix, the outlets are trying something new in a sleepy genre.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Sunday, CBS got the news it wanted for its new reality show, “Hunted.” With the aid of a muscular lead-in from an N.F.L. playoff game, the show had nearly 12 million viewers and the highest ratings for the premiere of a reality TV series since “The X-Factor” in 2011.

articles.headline: Trump to Order Mexican Border Wall and Curtail Immigration
articles.snippet: President Trump will order the construction of the wall on Wednesday and is mulling plans to bar Syrian refugees from the country.
articles.abstract: President Trump will order the construction of the wall on Wednesday and is mulling plans to bar Syrian refugees from the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Wednesday will order the construction of a Mexican border wall — the first in a series of actions this week to crack down on immigrants and bolster national security, including slashing the number of refugees who can resettle in the United States and blocking Syrians and others from “terror prone” nations from entering, at least temporarily.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis, David E. Sanger and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: How to Make America’s Robots Great Again
articles.snippet: Why a huge government investment in robots may be a great way to help American workers.
articles.abstract: Why a huge government investment in robots may be a great way to help American workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Factories play a central role in President Trump’s parade of American horrors. In his telling, globalization has left our factories “shuttered,” “rusted-out” and “scattered like tombstones across the landscape of our nation.”

articles.headline: After Trump Rejects Pacific Trade Deal, Japan Fears Repeat of 1980s
articles.snippet: The apparent death of the multinational trade deal could force Tokyo to negotiate one-on-one with the United States, provoking potentially bruising showdowns.
articles.abstract: The apparent death of the multinational trade deal could force Tokyo to negotiate one-on-one with the United States, provoking potentially bruising showdowns.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — President Trump’s decision to pull the United States out of the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal should have been good news for Hitoshi Kondo, a Japanese rice farmer.
